questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for ear carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common site for ear carcinoma is the pinna, followed by the external auditory meatus, the middle ear, and mastoid.

questions.text: Where are sebaceous cysts most commonly located in the ear?
questions.solution:
The most common site of a sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. Treatment is total surgical excision.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dark-colored summit over a swelling, usually seen in a sebaceous cyst.

Sebaceous cysts are the retention cysts of the sebaceous gland that are usually present on the face, scalp, or scrotum. They contain yellowish-white cheesy material with fat and epithelium.

Clinical features: 

  • The swelling is painless, soft, and freely mobile.
  • Though non-transilluminating, they are Paget's test positive (fluctuant).
  • Punctum is seen in 70% of the patients with sebaceous cysts. They are dark in color due to the accumulation of denuded epithelium.
  • They also have an unpleasant sebum odor.
  • The swelling can ulcerate and become painful (Cock’s peculiar tumor).
  • Some cysts over the scalp may also harden over time (Sebaceous horn).
  • Many may get infected and lead to abscess formation.

Treatment:

  • Excision including skin adjacent to punctum using elliptical incision-dissection method.
  • Incision and avulsion of cyst wall.
  • In the presence of an abscess, an initial treatment with an incision later followed by excision of the cyst

Other options:

Option A: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  1. Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development
  2. Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  3. Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  4. Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option C: Meningiomas are benign tumors arising from the meningothelial cells of the dura. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits.

Option D: Postauricular cutaneous mastoid fistula is a rare complication of chronic otitis media that heals very slowly and needs surgical closure.

questions.text: A surfer presented with hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in his ear. On otoscopy, multiple bony swellings were present in the external auditory canal. Which of the following features is diagnostic of exostosis?
questions.solution:
Exostoses are bilateral, multiple, smooth, sessile bony swellings in the deeper canal seen in divers/swimmers and surfers. It is also called as surfer’s ear.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with foul-smelling ear discharge and hearing loss for 1 year. On examination, a hemorrhagic polypoidal mass was seen in the middle ear. Biopsy revealed squamous cell carcinoma of the middle ear. Where is it least likely to spread to?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma is least likely to spread to the dura, as it is resistant to invasion.

It commonly affects middle-aged women. Other clinical features include-

  • Chronic foul-smelling discharge that is usually blood-stained.
  • Friable, hemorrhagic granulations
  • Polyp
  • Hearing loss

It usually spreads to

  • Ossicles
  • Facial canal
  • Internal ear
  • Jugular bulb & carotid artery
  • Petrous pyramid
  • Parotid & temporomandibular joint
  • Eustachian tube, Nasopharynx & Infratemporal fossa.

Lymph node involvement is a late finding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the middle ear?
questions.solution: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with progressive hearing loss and tinnitus is diagnosed to have a glomus tumor. Which cells do her tumor originate from?
questions.solution:
Glomus tumors originate from paraganglionic cells that are derived from neural crest cells. They are found in glomus bodies present in the dome of the jugular bulb or promontory. 

These cells are found in 2 sites giving rise to 2 similar yet distinct clinical tumors:

  • Glomus jugulare: in the jugular bulb
  • Glomus tympanicum: over the promontory along Jacobson’s nerve(IX nerve).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about paragangliomas of the head and neck?
questions.solution:
Paragangliomas of the head and neck, also known as glomus tumors, affect women more than men.

Glomus tumors are benign, non-encapsulated but vascular. They are extremely slow-growing, locally invasive, and often seen in middle age (40–50 years).

questions.text: What is the earliest symptom of glomus tumors?
questions.solution:
Earliest symptoms of glomus tumor are tinnitus and hearing loss.

Hearing loss is conductive and slowly progressive.

questions.text: You are a junior resident in the ENT department. A patient presents to you with pulsatile tinnitus. Which of the following will be your first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Glomus tumour will be your first differential diagnosis. Tinnitus in glomus tumors is:

  • Pulsatile
  • Of swishing character
  • Synchronous with pulse and
  • Can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with a glomus tumor and on otoscopy, see the following image. Which of the following signs is seen here?
questions.solution:
Rising sun sign is seen here, as it is a case of glomus tumor. The rising sun appearance is seen when a tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear. Otoscopy shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane. 

Option A - Cartwheel appearance is the leash of blood vessels appear along the handle of malleus and at the periphery of tympanic membrane.

Option B - Lighthouse sign is a pulsatile discharge from a pin-hole perforation of pars tensa seen in mastoiditis. 

Option D - Schwartze sign is the reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane in otosclerosis.

questions.text: While evaluating a patient with a suspected aural polyp, you apply Siegel's speculum and observe that the mass pulsates vigorously and then blanches. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The sign is called Brown’s sign or pulsation sign which is suggestive of glomus tumor.

When ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches. The reverse happens with the release of pressure.

Option A - Rising Sun sign is seen when glomus tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear.

Option B - Schwarze sign is the reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane in otosclerosis.

Option C - Lighthouse sign is a pulsatile discharge from a pin-hole perforation of pars tensa seen in mastoiditis.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, a polypoidal mass is seen in the middle ear, which bleeds heavily on touch. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of glomus tympanicum, a subtype of glomus tumors. 

Symptoms of glomus tumors:

  • Hearing loss
  • Tinnitus
  • Bleeding from the ear
  • Vertigo and facial palsy
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness of voice (cranial nerve palsies).

Examination findings:

  • Intratympanic tumor: rising sun appearance with a positive Brown sign
  • Red, vascular polyp that bleeds readily on manipulation or biopsy
  • Once the tympanic membrane is breached: bleeding polyp in the external ear
  • Audible bruit over the mastoid.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with hearing loss, pulsatile ringing in the right ear, and deviation of the tongue to the right side. MRI revealed a mass in the right jugular fossa. On examination, a pulsatile reddish mass was seen behind the intact tympanic membrane. Which of the following structures is invaded by the mass?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario of hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, 12th cranial nerve involvement, and red mass on otoscopy is suggestive of glomus jugulare. Hypotympanum is invaded by the tumor.

It arises in the adventitia of the dome of the jugular bulb and invades the hypotympanum, jugular foramen, and jugular vein.

In addition to ear signs and symptoms, cranial nerve involvement is commonly seen of the IXth to XIIth cranial nerves in glomus jugulare.

questions.text: A 45-year-old is referred to your ENT practice with pulsatile tinnitus, and Brown’s sign is positive. The patient gives you her CT films. Which of the following CT signs will help you differentiate between glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum?
questions.solution:
Phelp sign helps differentiate between glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum on CT.

It is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumors. It is intact in glomus tympanicum.

Option A - Battle's sign is ecchymosis over the mastoid seen in fractures of the temporal bone.

Option B - Lyre sign- splaying apart of internal and external carotid arteries on angiogram in cases of carotid body tumor of the neck. 

Option D - Griesinger's sign is edema over the mastoid and is seen in lateral sinus thrombosis.

The image given shows Battle's sign.

questions.text: A 68-year old woman presents with complaints of right-sided facial weakness for 15 days and progressive hearing loss for 2 years. On examination, there is tachycardia and carotid bruit on the right side. Otoscopy shows a red mass behind the tympanic membrane and 24-hour urine collection shows the presence of metanephrines. Which of the following classification systems is used for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with right-sided facial palsy, hearing loss, red mass behind the tympanic membrane, tachycardia, carotid bruit and positive urinary metanephrines is suggestive of a functional glomus tumor. 

10% of all glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines. This is diagnosed by testing the patient's 24-hour urine collection for urinary VMA (vanillylmandelic acid) or metanephrines. 

Glomus tumors are classified based on Fisch classification

Class Extent 
Class A Tumor limited to the middle ear (mesotympanum)
Class B

Tumor in the middle ear (meso- and hypotympanum) and the mastoid
Class C

Tumour originates in the dome of the jugular bulb, destroying the overlying bone and has extensive local spread.
Class D

Intracranial extension. It can be intradural or extradural

Option A: Lederman's classification is used in maxillary carcinoma.

Option C: Austin's classification is used to classify anatomical defects in the ossicular chain.

Option D: Sade's classification is used to classify atelectasis or retraction of the pars tensa.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with deafness, tinnitus, and bleeding from the ear. On examination, a reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane which blanches on applying pressure with the pneumatic speculum. Which of the following is not a part of its management?
questions.solution:
A pre-operative biopsy is not done in the management of glomus tumor due to the following reasons. 

  • Tumour is highly vascular and since the vessels lack the contractile musculature it bleeds profusely.
  • Risk of injury to
    • High jugular bulb 
    • Aberrant internal carotid artery 

Clinical and radiological features are enough to arrive at a diagnosis. Treatment consists of:

  • Surgical removal.
  • Radiation.
  • Embolization.
  • Combination of the above

Glomus tumor: Circled in red:

Note: Although CT is the test of choice for the evaluation of bone involvement, gadolinium-enhanced MRI provides a superior definition of the relationship of the tumor to adjacent vascular and skull base structures. Hence Both MRI and CT are typically needed for a suspected jugulotympanic paraganglioma given that the information derived from each study is complementary.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor at the cerebellopontine angle?
questions.solution:
Acoustic neuroma is the most common tumor at the cerebellopontine angle. It arises from the vestibular division of the VIIIth nerve within the internal auditory canal, widens and erodes the canal and appears at the cerebellopontine angle. 

Other tumors arising at the cerebellopontine angle are:

  • Meningioma
  • Cholesteatoma
  • Arachnoid cysts
  • Facial nerve schwannomas
  • Glomus tumor.

questions.text: Where does acoustic neuroma most commonly arise from?
questions.solution:
Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma almost always arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular division of 8th nerve.

It arises from the superior and the inferior division of the vestibular nerve in the medial internal auditory canal at the site of transition of central to peripheral myelin i.e., Obersteiner-Redlich zone.

Rarely, it can arise from the cochlear division of the 8th nerve within the internal auditory canal.

questions.text: Which of the following features is common to vestibular schwannomas and glomus tumors?
questions.solution:
Glomus tumors and vestibular shwannomas are both slow-growing, benign tumors of the temporal bone with locally invasive properties.

Vestibular shwannomas are encapsulated tumors. They are seen in middle aged individuals and have equal incidence in both sexes.

Glomus tumors are vascular paragangliomas and are non-encapsulated tumors. They are seen more commonly in middle-aged women.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptoms that acoustic neuroma presents with?
questions.solution:
Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the majority of cases.

Early symptoms of acoustic neuroma:

  • Progressive unilateral SNHL
  • Gross inability to understand speech out of proportion to the PTA average
  • Tinnitus
  • Unsteadiness and imbalance

The involvement of other cranial nerves leads to other deficits.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved in acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
The 8th cranial nerve is the earliest to be involved in acoustic neuroma.

Cochleovestibular symptoms are the earliest symptoms when the tumor is still intracanalicular and are caused by pressure on cochlear or vestibular nerve fibers or on the internal auditory artery.

Once the tumor erodes the canal, it presents in the cerebellopontine angle and can expand to involve other nearby cranial nerves such as the 5th and 7th cranial nerves.

Note: Acoustic neuroma arises from the 8th cranial nerve. Hence, it is the first nerve involved. However, if the 8th cranial nerve is not given as an option, then the answer would be the 5th cranial nerve.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss, decreased lacrimation, and loss of taste. On examining the external auditory meatus, there is decreased sensation on the posterior side. You suspect acoustic neuroma in this case. What sign was elicited here?
questions.solution:
Hitzelberger’s sign is the sign elicited in the given clinical scenario of acoustic neuroma.

Hitzelberger’s sign is the hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall because the tumor has affected the sensory fibers of the facial nerve. In this case, sensory fibers of the facial nerve are affected, as the patient has decreased lacrimation and loss of taste. Motor fibers are more resistant and are affected late. A delayed blink reflex may be an early manifestation.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation to confirm acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma.

It is superior to a CT scan. Intracanalicular tumors measuring even a few millimeters can be easily diagnosed by this method.

questions.text: A middle-aged-man presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. Which of the following features rules out Meniere’s disease and is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
Rollover phenomenon is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. It is a feature of retro-cochlear/neural lesions wherein the speech discrimination steadily increases with intensity but suddenly drops significantly beyond a particular intensity of sound.

Meniere’s disease is an important differential for acoustic neuroma as the patients suffer from similar symptoms. Meniere’s is a cochlear pathology and acoustic neuroma is retrocochlear.

Option A - Stapedial reflex is present in cochlear lesions (Meniere’s) and absent in retrocochlear lesion (acoustic neuroma)

Option B - Recruitment phenomenon is the abnormal growth in loudness in the affected ear, seen in cochlear pathologies. 

Option C - SISI (short increment sensitivity score) is a test of intensity discrimination which is very high in cochlear pathologies but low in retro-cochlear.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with difficulty hearing. Pure tone audiometry shows rollover phenomenon. An MRI with Gadolinium contrast shows a mass over the cerebellopontine angle. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acoustic neuroma. Treatment of choice in this case is surgery. 

The approach depends upon site and size of tumor:

  • Middle cranial fossa approach
  • Translabyrinthine approach
  • Retrosigmoid/Suboccipital approach
  • Combined.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of vestibular schwannomas?
questions.solution:
Cold knife is not used in the treatment of vestibular schwannomas. It is used for the conization of the cervix in cervical carcinoma.

Stereotactic radiosurgery is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. It can be done by using 

  • X-knife using a linear accelerator (LINAC)
  • Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60
  • CyberKnife - image-guided linear accelerator using real-time image guidance to deliver radiation from multiple angles.

External beam radiation is not recommended as it causes significant damage to the surrounding brain and neural structures.
